lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a video and answer comprehension questions about Sam and his life.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before video, give students three keywords to listen for. Pause after each section and ask: “Who’s that?” “What’s he like?”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise how Sam’s family is similar to or different from their own.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Ask: “How is Sam’s family different from yours?” Use a T-chart on the board: Sam’s / Mine. Fill it out together.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can discuss and think critically about why family and friends are important.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Ask: “Why are friends and family important?” Think–pair–share, then write 1–2 sentences and post on a class board.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
